articles.title: Untitled
articles.description: A new article created using the Distill format.
articles.contents:
NYC aggregate in-out flows
Next let’s examine the net inflow-outlow aggregate dataset by USPS.

# A tibble: 2 x 4
  covid_flag total_out total_in total_net_gain
  <chr>          <dbl>    <dbl>          <dbl>
1 covid         955779   603941        -351838
2 noncovid      654652   558893         -95759

Let’s look at that by borough.

# A tibble: 10 x 5
# Groups:   borough [5]
   borough       covid_flag total_out total_in total_net_gain
   <chr>         <chr>          <dbl>    <dbl>          <dbl>
 1 Bronx         covid          91783    65968         -25815
 2 Bronx         noncovid       85020    71110         -13910
 3 Brooklyn      covid         263551   178628         -84923
 4 Brooklyn      noncovid      183116   159032         -24084
 5 Manhattan     covid         378823   187619        -191204
 6 Manhattan     noncovid      199748   164610         -35138
 7 Queens        covid         192755   144656         -48099
 8 Queens        noncovid      159559   137961         -21598
 9 Staten Island covid          28867    27070          -1797
10 Staten Island noncovid       27209    26180          -1029

Let’s look at it through the lens of time and money.

Net flows by month
We can see the enormous exodus that happened in March 2020 and the subsequent months, with a rebound as the year progressed.
The city was still losing more people on a net basis, but the gradually less than before.
